title: Comparing z-Scores: Danielle's Tests Scores
question_text:
Danielle had an AP Statistics test and AP US History test on the same day. On the AP Statistics test, the average score was an $81$, with a standard deviation of $4$. On the AP U.S. History Test, the average score was $73$, with a standard deviation of $8$. Danielle scored a $77$ on the AP Statistics test and $67$ on the AP U.S. History test. Assume the scores of each test were approximately normally distributed.
On which test did Danielle score relatively better, compared with the rest of the class?

choices.text: She scored better on the AP Statistics test relative to the rest of the class.
She scored better on the AP U.S. History test relative to the rest of the class.
She scored equally well on both tests.
It is impossible to tell because we do not have all the individual scores from each test.
It is impossible to tell because we do not know the shape of the distribution.

solution:
To answer this question, you must be able to correctly find and interpret the $z$-scores. You need to know the general formula of:

$$\text{Standardized test statistic }=\dfrac {\text{statistic-parameter} }{\text{standard deviation of statistic}}$$

In this case:

$$z=\dfrac { x-\mu }{ \sigma }$$

Danielle's AP Statistics $z$-score and interpretation is as follows:

$$z=\frac { 77-81 }{ 4 } =-1$$

Therefore, Danielle scored one standard deviation below the mean on her AP Statistics test.

Danielle's AP U.S. History $z$-score and interpretation:

$$ z=\frac { 67-73 }{ 8 } =-0.75$$

Danielle scored $.75$ standard deviations below the mean on her AP U.S. History test. This is a higher $z$-score compared to her AP Statistics $z$-score, as $-0.75 > -1$.

Choice 'B': This is correct. Danielle's $z$-score was higher on the AP U.S. History Test.

Explanation of Distractors

Choice 'A': This is incorrect, as her $z$-score was higher on the AP U.S. History test.

Choice 'C': This is incorrect. Danielle's $z$-scores were different on both tests.

Choice 'D': This is incorrect. We do not need to know all the students' scores from each test, just the average and standard deviation in order to compute the $z$-score.

Choice 'E': This is incorrect. The problem states the scores were normally distributed for each test, therefore we can use $z$-scores to solve the problem.
